ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live virtual lecture by Professor Adelstein & recorded lecture by Professor Hall.
Peer tutor zoom meetings, pre-lecture videos and quizzes.
There was a live virtual lecture component, which was taught by Professor Adelstein, and there were pre-recorded sections, to be watched before class, by Professor Hall.
The class was live virtual lectures accompanied by recorded lectures.
Live virtual lectures with student engagement via polls and group problems (breakout rooms).
In-person seminar, recorded videos posted by course instructor
We watched pre-recorded lecture videos asynchronously, but we also had synchronous in-person classes that were lectures but in a small group with interactive components.
Recorded videos on every topic of Math 120
Office hours over zoom
Along with live virtual lectures, there were prerecorded lectures we watched before class.
Recorded videos and live section with class
Recorded lectures for preclass viewing
part recorded lecture and part virtual seminar
Live virtual lecture included break-out problem-solving sessions.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I gained a good knowledge base surrounding 3D geometry and interpretation of higher dimensional calculus. I gained insight into the practical application of some concepts in the course.
I learned calculus and practiced what we learned in class with our weekly problem sets.

I learned the basic concepts of multivariable calculus as well as how to visualize 3D space and graphs in 3D space. I learned problem-solving skills and how to practice to best digest the information, not through reading the concepts again, but through doing practice problems and ramping up the difficulty of this practice.
Multivariable knowledge definitely came easy to me in this course! But the time management for studying for an exam was a useful skill to foster early on.
I have learned a lot about multivariable calculus and new methods to solve problems of this nature.
I learned about a wide spread of multivariable calculus topics and how they can work together. The focus of this course is mainly theoretical, but the final project is more practical.
I learned the topics of multivariable calculus, and the methods best suited to furthering my understanding of math topics.

I developed my understanding of multivariable calculus through both a geometric and algebraic lens throughout this course. I definitely have a better understanding of how functions of multiple variables work in three dimensions and how the calculus of these functions takes shape. Additionally, I found that this course touched on various applications to physics and engineering, which I found both interesting and applicable to other courses I was taking.
I gained a better fundamental understanding of calculus and learned how to do it in higher dimensions.

I learned the importance of Multivariable Calculus in building 3D Models, Vectors , how certain formulas can be applied in higher dimensions and the application of certain integrals in a physical setting.
Multivariable calculus!
I learned multivariable calculus
I learned a lot of foundational multivariable calculus techniques that I think will be useful as I take future STEM-related classes.
Multivariable calculus, how to draw 3D graphs, how to think about math at the college level
Introduction to vectors, multivariable optimization, important theorems in multivariable calculus (Green's Theorem, Divergence Theorem, Stoke's Theorem, etc).

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The strengths of this course would be some of the professors, especially Professor Hall, and the midterm review content, which if used correctly could save you on the exams. The weaknesses of this course include some of the professors, the difficulty of the exams, an extremely unforgiving grade curve, and the final project, which was very difficult to complete and had relatively unclear expectations with no examples given.

I enjoyed the course, I thought that its structure was good because the discussion sections weren't very large so we had the opportunity to ask questions and Professor Hall's videos were helpful as well.

I think the lecture style is helpful, with breakout rooms, examples, and group problems. I liked that the problem sets were hard, so it forced me to work with other people, both students and peer tutors, and they prepared me well for the exams. I didn't like the pre-class lectures and quizzes. I thought they weren't very helpful, and yet took a lot of time.

Strengths are definitely the difficulty and collaborative nature of the problem sets, as I loved brainstorming with friends on how to conceptualize a problem that required an extreme abstract thought process. A specific weakness is hard to pinpoint, as the class was carried out as advertised so I never felt like the course blindsided me or did anything that was unexpected.

The strengths of this course were the layout of the course, which divides the students into smaller sections for more personalized attention from the professor, and the organization of the course, as past practice tests served as test prep and quizzes served to confirm our understanding of the new content.

I enjoyed this class. It was fun and engaging and the material was digestible.  The one thing I would say that could be improved is the timeline for assignments. I really wish the recorded lectures were uploaded early so that I could better budget my time and be prepared for the quizzes as well as class; Sometimes the volume of videos was a lot for one class.
The virtual lecture was as good and engaging of an experience as I could hope for from a virtual course.

The strengths of this course was its thoroughness in explaining the material and the resources for help which were made available. I found one weakness to be that material introduced in pre-lecture videos was often repeated in class. Although this was sometimes helpful to clarify things and expand on topics, I sometimes found it to be redundant.

This class's combination of asynchronous lectures and synchronous classes was very strong. I liked being able to learn something for the first time in the videos, then ask questions in class. Tests were also always very fair. One weakness was psets, as they sometimes felt more like busywork, with really long calculations, rather than an opportunity to practice and learn.

The strengths of the course included John Halls recorded Unit topics following the James Stewart Multivariable calculus textbook and the in class lectures I and with Ian Adelstein who would cover the same information as the Unit Video recordings.

Professor Adelstein did a great job facilitating close to an in- class environment by asking students to answer and give questions frequently on the material. Furthermore, there would constantly be break out rooms and live true or false question polls that were answered.

Weaknesses:
The length of the class over zoom and the engagement of students during lectures
I like how each class is smaller in size, because it made it a bit easier to connect with the class being online.
I love the format it translated really nicely online

I think one of the course's strengths was that it was very organized, which made it much easier to see connections between topics and between different dimensions of the same ideas/theorems. Peer tutor hours were also very widely accessible.
I absolutely loved the videos from John hall teaching the subjects before the lectures.

There were lots of office hours and peer tutoring hours each week, which was helpful.

I felt that a weakness of the course was the way workload was structured. Before each class, students were required to watch 30-45 minute recorded clips and complete a pre-class quiz. In addition, there were weekly p-sets, three exams for the course, and a final project. I found this workload to be extremely heavy and wish there was a better balance. Also, I wish that class sessions were recorded, so that students could go back and re-watch class content.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The virtual review sessions for midterms were very helpful, and every extra recorded video from Professor Hall from the individual lessons all the way to the final project were much appreciated. The biggest flaw of this course was that the lessons were not recorded, which made it extremely difficult to keep up with this course if we ever fell behind in a lecture. Another learning practice that should be abolished is the group breakout rooms. I was rarely in a breakout room that benefitted my knowledge in any way, and generally they were the most dreaded part of class for me.
I'm not sure which practices were geared toward virtual learning and which were part of the course originally, but I thought that its virtual format was still engaging.

I think the use of breakout rooms to work through group problems in lecture was very effective as well as the use of polling to test our knowledge particularly on true/false problems that are helpful to practice for exams.

Recording of lectures may have been useful, as the notes from class were nice to review examples as practice but no clear recording was provided for the thought process that accompanied them. I absolutely loved watching the recorded review sessions as they were always at very inconvenient times (personally) but were made very easy to use for practice when viewed later on.

I understand that dividing us into smaller groups is the normal layout for MATH120, and I believe that this is the best method to each math; however, I still felt a bit disjointed and unengaged. I believe that the use of breakout rooms, JamBoard, and Zoom quizzes did increase the engagement of the course greatly, I still noticed myself zoning out at times.

I found this class worked really well online. I was able to access resources to help me when I was confused and was able to learn the material. I especially liked the final project as it was a lot of fun and helped me understand some innovative ways to apply multivariate calculus.

The polls and group work during lectures were very helpful, as they helped solidify the concepts of the lecture. The peer tutor office hours were helpful for the problem sets, but I do wish that some effort had been made to help students form study groups.

I think the use of breakout rooms in class made it easier to get to know students in the class. I would have liked a little more guidance on and facilitation of the group project at the end of the semester. I found it difficult at times to complete this project while only able to work virtually for most of its duration.
As mentioned, I think the two-pronged teaching method worked well.

The breakout rooms with individual students worked as well as the videos and pre class quizzes posted by John Hall regularly. Furthermore, the Ximera website resources also helped expand my knowledge on the topics.

The weaknesses were the lack of practice of certain topics during class even though there were break out rooms usually designed for us to solve problems.
I liked how we did breakout rooms almost every class. It was a good way to talk to classmates, switch it up, and practice problems.
The video lessons worked really well. I liked this course.
The videos were amazing, although I never used Ximera. I found the examples too easy.

The course had three exams and a final project. I personally felt this was an extremely heavy workload, given that students were expected to also complete weekly psets and do three sit-down exams. I would have preferred if there were two exams and a final project.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would not recommend this course unless you fall into specific categories. If you honestly think you have a "love" or "passion" for math, give it a go and enjoy. I took multivariable in high school and its potentially different with COVID, but I do not feel this course taught me well and in fact I feel my multivariable knowledge is less complete from this course compared to before. If you are like me and are required to take this course for your major based on the placement exam, you'll be fine but expect to put in work if you want to stay ahead of the class curve, which was significantly more aggressive than my other classes this semester.
Yes!

I would recommend this course to another student if they want to pursue math or fulfill a math requirement (but looking for a challenge). The course takes more time and work than you may expect and is more difficult than I was expecting. It takes a lot of self-motivated study, but if you are willing to ask for help, go to peer tutoring, and put in the work, it is a far more interesting way to fulfill a math credit.
This course is great for students who felt they have a good handle on Calc 2 material, but for those who do not feel strong with said amterial, I may not recommend this course specifically.

Yes, I would recommend this course to others, as it is well taught and very informative. I believe that many students could gain a lot from taking this course, especially if they have never taken multivariate calculus before, as the applications of multivariate calculus in the world of academic are immense.
Yes! I would just suggest brushing up on some of the material beforehand.
I would recommend this course as a solid introduction to multivariate calculus.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student if you have an interest in math, physics, engineering, or any related STEM subject. This course is a great introduction to calculus in 3-space, and it provides a thorough explanation as to how a lot of the math one may have learned throughout high school applies to the physical world.

This course is very challenging, but very well taught. Everything is very well planned out and organized throughout, and the class really fits together in a very satisfying way at the end. If you like math, take the course. If you don't, proceed with caution.

Yes, If the student wants to become an engineer or use in some field of science or math, this class is a must. The professors simplify the topics and you will come out with a strong base for higher level mathematics including linear algebra.
Yes, it gave me a good foundation for Econ 121
Only if you need it for either the Econ or Math major.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student, at least from the perspective who took BC Calculus in high school (but had no multivariable experience before taking this course). I felt like the course content was not particularly difficult to understand as long as you did the pre-class readings properly. The course is also useful as a prerequisite for a lot of other things.

Yes, I thought that it had an amazing structure, and I liked the whole ecosystem of this class, ie being part of both a section and the umbrella 120 community that included videos and review sessions and peer tutors.

I would recommend this course to a student who is studying a STEM subject and needs a multivariable calculus background. I would not necessarily recommend this course to students who are simply looking to fulfill a QR credit; the course/exams were extremely difficult and despite so, the grading scheme isn't generous because most people have taken multivariable calculus before or seem to have very a strong background in mathematics.
